siteMetadata.title: Autokin Automation
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using the Apollo GraphQL Client with React

children.value: Note: Apollo no longer ships with Flow types. If you want to help contribute to add these, please reach out!
As your application grows, you may find it helpful to include a type system to assist in development. Apollo supports type definitions for TypeScript out of the box. Both
ship with definitions in their npm packages, so installation should be done for you after the libraries are included in your project.
These docs assume you already have TypeScript configured in your project, if not start

The most common need when using type systems with GraphQL is to type the results of an operation. Given that a GraphQL server's schema is strongly typed, we can even generate TypeScript definitions automatically using a tool like
. In these docs however, we will be writing result types manually.
Using Apollo together with TypeScript couldn't be easier than using it with component API released in React Apollo 2.1:

in our tree to get full TypeScript support! Since we are not mapping any props coming into our component, nor are we rewriting the props passed down, we only need to provide the shape of our data and the variables required for it to work! Everything else is handled by React Apollo's robust type definitions.
This approach is the exact same for the
components! Learn it once, and get the best types ever with Apollo.

properties.ariaLabel: typing the higher order components permalink

children.value: Since the result of a query will be sent to the wrapped component as props, we want to be able to tell our type system the shape of those props. Here is an example setting types for an operation using the
: the follow sections also work for the query, mutation, and subscription hocs):
// Note that the first parameter here is an empty Object, which means we're
// not checking incoming props for type safety in this example. The next
// example (in the "Options" section) shows how the type safety of incoming

Typically, variables to the query will be computed from the props of the wrapper component. Wherever the component is used in your application, the caller would pass arguments that we want our type system to validate what the shape of these props could look like. Here is an example setting the type of props:

This is especially helpful when accessing deeply nested objects that are passed down to the component through props. For example, when adding prop types, a project using TypeScript will begin to surface errors where props being passed are invalid:
// $ExpectError property `episode`. Property not found in. See: src/Character.js:43
One of the most powerful feature of the React integration is the

function which allows you to reshape the result data from an operation into a new shape of props for the wrapped component. GraphQL is awesome at allowing you to only request the data you want from the server. The client still often needs to reshape or do client side calculations based on these results. The return value can even differ depending on the state of the operation (i.e loading, error, recieved data), so informing our type system of choice of these possible values is really important to make sure our components won't have runtime errors.
supports manually declaring the shape of your result props.
Since we have typed the response shape, the props shape, and the shape of what will be passed to the client, we can prevent errors in multiple places. Our options and props function within the
wrapper are now type safe, our rendered component is protected, and our tree of components have their required props enforced.
// $ExpectError [string] This type cannot be compared to number
// $ExpectError property `isHero`. Property not found on object type

With this addition, the entirety of the integration between Apollo and React can be statically typed. When combined with the strong tooling each system provides, it can make for a much improved application and developer experience.
All of the above examples show wrapping a component which is just a function using the result of a
wrapper. Sometimes, components that depend on GraphQL data require state and are formed using the
practice. In these use cases, TypeScript requires adding prop shape to the class instance. In order to support this,
exports types to support creating result types easily.
property in the configuration of the
wrapper, you will need to manually attach the type of the response to the
function. An example using TypeScript would be like this:
// $ExpectError [string] This type cannot be compared to number
// $ExpectError property `isHero`. Property not found on object type
